update.title: Joints

content.raw:
Hum, I'm not sure what you mean by the plane of wheels here. 

According to the universal joint [documentation](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/7298099ad5967af3b9207ae93ae309ee861fd31c/gazebo/physics/UniversalJoint.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#UniversalJoint.hh-31), the first axis is attached to the parent (the chassis) and the second is attached to the child (the wheel). So the axis in which the wheels rotate forward and backwards is axis 2. Axis 1 is the steering axis, so even as the wheels spin, it is still vertical. Does that make sense?

And to make things more complicated, even though axis1 is attached to the parent, its initial state is defined in the child link frame. Take a look, the cart on the right is in the initial pose, and the one on the left has moved:

![universalcart.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/RMMxjX/images/2550497189-universalcart.png)

See how axis 1 is defined in the negative Y axis of the cylinder, but doesn't remain on the cylinder's -Y. It remains fixed to the chassis.
content.html:
Hum, I'm not sure what you mean by the plane of wheels here.

According to the universal joint documentation, the first axis is attached to the parent (the chassis) and the second is attached to the child (the wheel). So the axis in which the wheels rotate forward and backwards is axis 2. Axis 1 is the steering axis, so even as the wheels spin, it is still vertical. Does that make sense?

And to make things more complicated, even though axis1 is attached to the parent, its initial state is defined in the child link frame. Take a look, the cart on the right is in the initial pose, and the one on the left has moved:

See how axis 1 is defined in the negative Y axis of the cylinder, but doesn't remain on the cylinder's -Y. It remains fixed to the chassis.

content.raw:
That's interesting, I didn't know that universal joints force the axes to be perpendicular. I just created one non perpendicular with the model editor and the physics engine immediately forced the bodies to be perpendicular.

I just didn't understand very well what you meant by the rotation being equal. It sounds like the rotations are coupled, which it's not the case. But maybe you meant something else?
content.html:
That's interesting, I didn't know that universal joints force the axes to be perpendicular. I just created one non perpendicular with the model editor and the physics engine immediately forced the bodies to be perpendicular.

I just didn't understand very well what you meant by the rotation being equal. It sounds like the rotations are coupled, which it's not the case. But maybe you meant something else?

content.raw:
@meha27 , could you pull from the OSRF repository and merge the branch with yours? The live version has everything under a lower-cased [directory](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/src/925b1d638ca7657475b1110bc21789ef8cdb3788/joints/?at=Joints) `joints`.

You should be able to do it like this:

~~~
hg up Joints
hg pull #!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials -b Joints
hg merge          (make sure the merge is correct and all the latest files are under the correct directory)
hg commit -m "message here"
~~~
content.html:
@meha27 , could you pull from the OSRF repository and merge the branch with yours? The live version has everything under a lower-cased directory joints.

You should be able to do it like this:

hg up Joints
hg pull #!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials -b Joints
hg merge          (make sure the merge is correct and all the latest files are under the correct directory)
hg commit -m "message here"

content.raw: It looks like the text is wrapping in a strange way. Meha, would it be possible to make the images smaller (by about half) and make the text appear below each image?
content.html: It looks like the text is wrapping in a strange way. Meha, would it be possible to make the images smaller (by about half) and make the text appear below each image?

content.raw: I think the tutorial so far is doing a good job in explaining joint types. It would be nice to also explain some other common parameters. People are usually quite confused by joint pose and axis, so those might be nice to begin with.
content.html: I think the tutorial so far is doing a good job in explaining joint types. It would be nice to also explain some other common parameters. People are usually quite confused by joint pose and axis, so those might be nice to begin with.

content.raw: I like the two ragdolls example, I think this is actually a very common use of fixed joints. You could mention that the torso is the link which is fixed to the world.
content.html: I like the two ragdolls example, I think this is actually a very common use of fixed joints. You could mention that the torso is the link which is fixed to the world.

content.raw: Should we add some text here?
I like the simple arm example. I think that having this one as well might make people confused, because the cubes don't really look like pedals and it's hard to imagine how the joint will move.
content.html: I like the simple arm example. I think that having this one as well might make people confused, because the cubes don't really look like pedals and it's hard to imagine how the joint will move.

content.raw: What do you think of some motion like [this](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=flU_zvRO8Z4)?  I think ideally we would show both joints moving, but that might be hard to setup just from the GUI. I think it would be nice at least to turn the wheels to show they have an extra DOF in relation to the back wheels.
content.html: What do you think of some motion like this? I think ideally we would show both joints moving, but that might be hard to setup just from the GUI. I think it would be nice at least to turn the wheels to show they have an extra DOF in relation to the back wheels.

content.raw: It would be nice to see the steering angle moving too. Let me know if you need help ;)
content.html: It would be nice to see the steering angle moving too. Let me know if you need help ;)

content.raw: You can add a new line here to make the text start in a new paragraph
content.html: You can add a new line here to make the text start in a new paragraph

content.raw: What's the difference between "translation" and "sliding linear motion"?
content.html: What's the difference between "translation" and "sliding linear motion"?

content.raw:
We could use sub headers for each joint type, like:

~~~
## Revolute

A hinge joint...

~~~
content.html:
We could use sub headers for each joint type, like:

## Revolute

A hinge joint...

content.raw:
Thanks for the tutorial, @meha27 !

I pulled it in an made some changes to the manifest. Each tutorial needs a unique reference, and the proper path to its directory. Also, the convention is to have directory names lower cased. You should be able to update this tutorial by pulling from the osrf repo.

Here's a preview:

http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?branch=Joints&tut=joints
content.html:
Thanks for the tutorial, @meha27 !

I pulled it in an made some changes to the manifest. Each tutorial needs a unique reference, and the proper path to its directory. Also, the convention is to have directory names lower cased. You should be able to update this tutorial by pulling from the osrf repo.

Here's a preview:

http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?branch=Joints&tut=joints
